thread.title: With drones in tow, Anderson debuts 'Junun' documentary
thread.title_full: With drones in tow, Anderson debuts 'Junun' documentary

title: With drones in tow, Anderson debuts 'Junun' documentary
text:
With drones in tow, Anderson debuts 'Junun' documentary   4:00   4:00 PM EDT 
NEW YORK (AP) â€” Filmmaker Paul Thomas Anderson premiered his first documentary, "Junun," on Thursday at the New York Film Festival, unveiling a sonically rich portrait of Indian musicians recording an album with Radiohead's Johnny Greenwood. 
The film, just under an hour long, plunges into their recording sessions, along with Israeli composer Shye Ben Tzur, during a three-week trip to Rajasthan in northwestern India. With scant interviews, and hardly any words from Greenwood, "Junun" instead captures the musicians in full thrall, recording in a hilltop fort in between occasional power outages. 
"Junun" will be released on the movie subscription platform MUBI on Friday. Anderson shot it digitally, occasionally even experimenting with drones. 
Greenwood has scored Anderson's last three films: "There Will Be Blood," ''The Master" and "Inherent Vice."
